damaged terrain so yeah that was a recreation of something that happened to

here big chunk ripped out revealing the beautiful pink foam inside so today I'm
gonna fix it if you have managed to damage one of your hard built pieces of
terrain have no fear even a building like this can be saved if it has taken
some minimal damage now first of all let me say that had this thing been made out
of plaster and fallen to the floor like that
it quite possibly could have shattered into many pieces
luckily because it's foam it probably mostly bounced and it just got this one
piece of foam ripped out where it must have hit something pretty hard so the
first thing you need to do obviously is assess the damage and I've taken a look
over this thing the spikes you know that were bent or
easy to put back not a big deal this spot here seems to be the only bit of
damage next thing you have to do is decide how you want to approach the
repair there's two things you could do one is you could leave the gouge and
basically just repaint that so that it blends in that's the quickest easiest
way to do it and on a piece like this you could definitely get away with that
because it would just add to you know the the look of the piece having a big
chunk of stone missing it really would make sense but that would be a shorter
video and not quite as interesting so I am going to attempt to actually make
this disappear whether or not this works I am not 100% sure but let's see what we
can do the first thing you need is some kind of repair compound get yourself a
little container and some filler I use all-purpose drywall filler you buy this
at the hardware store get a little tub whatever it's pre-mixed so you want to
take some of this once you got some in your container there we want to add
something to make this stuff stronger than it is naturally get your
all-purpose white PVA glue squirt a bunch in don't ask me about ratio
because I don't know it just make it up as you go along but for those of you
that need a ratio let's say one part glue to five parts joint compound mix
this up you'll find that PVA glue and filler don't like to mix nicely they
tend to kind of fight and it turns into a very hard kind of rubbery compound
almost immediately that is sort of what you want now this part is optional but I
like to do it whenever I'm making kind of filler like this I like to mix in
black paint right off the bat save you some effort later when your base coating
don't worry too much about the ratio but don't make the mistake I just did and
put way too much all right from the beginning definitely could have used a
lot less adding some paint also helps whenever you're mixing stuff together
because it lets you know once you have it consistently mixed so take your piece
and your filler small amount and basically just need to fill in that
chunk there what you are trying to do here is to fill this area in with a
certain amount of excess so that you can shape it later so once you have a big
mound of this compound on the piece you're gonna want to shape it slightly
and to do this just use a finger but make sure it has some water or spit on
it and basically if it's a right angle like this you want to just kind of
sculpt it from one side using the existing surface as a guide basically
just run your hand over it and do the same on the top you want to go very
gently and try to make that corner each time you do it from one side it's gonna
want to push that edge bulging over the other side and you just kind of have to
carefully go back and forth between the two sides until you get what you want
you might find that you get a bit of buildup or bumps in the corners so just
take a wet brush and kind of work the compound smooth you don't have any
ugly lumps same thing on the front and already even with just the filler and no
paint this bit of damage is starting to disappear and this is the nice thing
about mixing the black paint into the compound
everything that spreads out in excess isn't like a big ugly white streak now
that this patch has dried it already looks pretty darn good I could probably
get away with just leaving it as is but it's still visible if you really look
this patch compound that I put over you know it's kind of spread out across a
large area here and I could touch up all of the paint but I think I want to try
to reduce this patch back down to only the spot that was damaged so I do less
touch-up paint what I'm gonna do is I'm just gonna take a wet brush and try to
wipe away some of the excess that's just on the flat sections really thin usually
the toilet paper to dry it off and I think that it's working a little bit
tough to tell because it might just be making it look wet but hatch looks
really good I can barely tell where it even is but
it's right here I mean really I could totally just leave it I don't think it
needs much else just to try to get it 100 percent
I'm gonna do a bit of a light gray dry brushing just to get it a little bit
more similar to the rest of the stone because this thing has have so many
washes on it during the build it's a little tough to say what shade of gray
to use but I'm going to take bit of this gray just a really really small amount
this gray might actually be too dark but I don't want to put something too bright
on first see now with that dry brush it carries
this high light line right across the new patch so you really don't see it and
just to make sure it really blends in with the original I'm gonna take some of
my cheap black wash and just put a little bit on it and soak up some of
this excess here that's run down
so after letting the wash dry for about half an hour I completed the repair by
taking this thing to the basement and giving it a light misting with Minwax
polyurethane that I covered in a previous episode that I used to seal all
my styrofoam projects and this just completed the patch by giving it a you
know slightly glossy look like the rest of the piece and while it's not a
hundred percent if you look closely and know that it's there you can see that it
looks slightly different but even on a close inspection I don't think it looks
like a patch and for anybody who didn't know or wasn't looking I would say that
this patch is a hundred percent blended I am going to call this repair a success
now how well it would work on a much larger repair I'm unsure and I hope I
